conclusion: Analyze the acceleration-time graph to determine when the object's velocity is at its maximum.
The graph shows acceleration on the y-axis and time on the x-axis. Acceleration starts at +2 m/s² and decreases linearly to -2 m/s² over 4 seconds.
Velocity is the integral of acceleration.
Integrate a(t) to find v(t): v(t) = 2t - 1/2t² + C.
Since the object starts from rest, v(0) = 0, so C = 0.
Take the derivative of v(t) and set it to zero to find maximum velocity: dv/dt = 2 - t = 0.
Check the second derivative to confirm it's a maximum: d²v/dt² = -1.
Since the second derivative is negative, t = 2 seconds is indeed a maximum.
The object's velocity is at its maximum at t = 2 seconds.
